title: CSS Media Queries
subject: CSS
theory:
Media queries allow you to apply specific styles depending on the screen size, print mode, or orientation.

Key Concept: **Breakpoints**. These are pixel widths where the layout 'breaks' or changes to adapt to the new size.

*   `min-width`: Applies if screen is AT LEAST this wide (Desktop-first style).
*   `max-width`: Applies if screen is AT MOST this wide (Mobile-first style).

examples.output: Flex items stack vertically on tablets and phones.

common_mistakes.correction: Ensure your breakpoints don't conflict. usually spacing them out (e.g. 600px, 900px, 1200px) is best.

interview_questions.question: What is Mobile-First design?
interview_questions.answer: Writing styles for mobile devices first (default), then using `min-width` media queries to add styles for larger screens.

practice_problems.problem: Hide an element on screens smaller than 500px.

real_world_use_cases.description: Using `@media print` to hide navigation and ads when the user prints the page.

summary: Media queries are the engine behind Responsive Web Design.
